channel.title: Html
channel.description:
I was just wondering a few things, while looking at different languages, HTML seems to be the easiest, am I right? and will learning HTML help me with java?
PS: I found an HTML for dummies book in my house today, didn't know I had it so I'm wondering if it will help me.

item.title: Html
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

TheCyberMan:

I remember a couple days ago, a 7th grader at my old school was asking if it was hard to code some game I made in HTML. I was like, it’s a form of Javascript called Unity Script. And he was like, “No, it’s HTML.”

Lol

Read full topic

item.title: Html
item.dc:creator: @demps2k9 demps2k9
item.description:
@demps2k9 wrote:

[quote=“The Djinn, post:6, topic:414781”]HTML isn’t even close to C++.

Webpages = HTML, CSS, PHP.

Html is used to make basic web pages yes, but you’ll need to know CSS as well to make a decent layout if you know what you’re doing.[/quote]

I believe you don’t need CSS to make a decent layout. It is more efficient using CSS but I can make layouts using simple tables.

item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

imsuperman05:

Java is really easy to learn. Java is used in most programs today, and can benefit in getting a job in today’s economy(assuming you live in the US).

Yes I do live in the US, and I have been looking for classes I can take but there are very few on Java, but I am waiting until next year to start Duel Enrollment in my school so I can take Programming Classes.

item.title: Html
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:21, topic:414781”]How is:

any simpler than

less keys to hit?

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:22, topic:414781”]If newCustomer = True Then newCustomer = False End If

Boolean operators are the same as assignment… That causes all sorts of problems when you switch to other languages[/quote]
true

our programming course started with vb, then c#, then now java.

OT: i found these lecture videos useful, if u want to learn from watching a lecture. http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/electrical-engineering-and-computer-science/6-00-introduction-to-computer-science-and-programming-fall-2008/video-lectures/ not only will you get an understanding of programming but you will be learning python. ik python is used quite a bit, google uses python in most of their open-source projects ive used(chromium, native client[used for compiling]). plus you will be able to program in jython. I started out learning javascript and html, which didnt help much. but the videos i listed above should help, i havent watched them all b/c they are 1 hr long and I dont really have the time.

Read full topic

If newCustomer = True Then newCustomer = False End If

Boolean operators are the same as assignment… That causes all sorts of problems when you switch to other languages

item.title: Html
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Pure Slay, post:19, topic:414781”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=516742.msg3752571#msg3752571 date=1316143000]

NO! DON’T USE BASIC!

Use Java, C#, or C++ if you’re trying to start with object oriented programming.
If you’ve learned other languages sure, it doesn’t hurt to know another, but starting with basic will set you back a LOT if you try to ever learn other languages

You do realize that all introductory college level classes start with some form of BASIC.
[/quote]Mine doesn’t? And I completely agree with HcoJustin.

That’s odd, because almost every program structure classes that I have looked at, and currently enrolled in. Deal with something related to BASIC. I’m not saying it’s a grand language, nor suggesting to fully learn it. Although it helps new programmers with basic concepts that all programming languages structure. I personally know BASIC, Java, and the mark up language HTML. I can honestly say I had no difficulty changing between them, you just need to realize that every programming language has its own rules and ways of programming it. Some represent similar structure, and syntax which people automatically assume makes it ‘easier’. Regardless, in his position where he doesn’t seem to know any programming language. I’d suggest just looking over examples of it, since it is literally baby programming. That way he understands IF whatever, does this. How to store values to variables, and may understand a bit about loops. If he feels prepared enough that he can just jump into a language, go for it. Although like I mentioned before, most programming logical/structure classes do touch on a language similar to, or is BASIC.[/quote]BASIC doesn’t make those concepts any simpler.

How is:

any simpler than

Read full topic

item.title: Html
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

[code]CIS - Computer Information Systems

CIS 103 - Fund Prog Internet
A course that presents the concepts of writing computer programs for use on the Internet (Formerly CIS118)

CIS 193G - Mobile Device Prog
Provides students with insights and experience with an existing mobile development platform. Covers considerations of mobile development and the current platform.

CIS 201 - Intro To Comp Sci
Introduces students to the Computer Science discipline. Problem solving and using computers to solve problems. Transfer: CSU; UC. (Formerly CIS1)

CIS 210 - Intro Cmptr Applic
Introduces computer terminology, relationship between hardware and software, and the use of computer operating systems, application software, Web features, and linking between application programs. Prerequisite: ENGL 156 or eligibility for ENGL 201A Advisory: CAOA 120A, CAOA 162 or ability to type 25 words per minute. Transfer: CSU; UC. (Formerly CIS10)

CIS 217 - “C” Prog Language
Presents a course in programming computers using the “C” programming language. Transfer: CSU; UC. (Formerly CIS17)

CIS 224 - Database Admin
Provides the knowledge and skills required to use, install, configure, administer, and troubleshoot a relational database management system (RDBMS). Topics include constructing and using Structured Query Language (SQL) statements, understanding RDBMS architecture, installing or upgrading a RDBMS, managing storage, managing RDBMS security, backing up and restoring data, managing performance, and implementing high availability. Advisory: CNET 221 or CIS 222 or CAOA 264. (Formerly CIS141)

CIS 231 - Fund Comp Science I
Presents the fundamentals of an engineering approach to software development. Intended for Computer Science Majors. Transfer: CSU; UC. (Formerly CIS31)

CIS 232 - Fund Comp Sci II
Continues fundamentals of computer programming with emphasis on the use of abstract data types such as tables, stacks, queues, and lists. Uses procedural and object oriented methods to develop software solutions. Presents classic algorithmic techniques such as searching, sorting, and recursion. Prerequisite: CIS 231 Transfer: CSU; UC (Formerly CIS32)

CIS 233 - Fund Comp Sci III
Introduces advanced concepts including: theory, generic programming implementation, applications, and analysis of associated algorithms including lists, stacks, queues, hash tables, trees, and graphs. Recursion, iteration, searching, and sorting algorithms and analysis. Prerequisite: CIS 232 Corequisite: CIS 241 Transfer: CSU; UC (For UC, both CIS 232 and 233 must be completed in order to receive transfer units). (Formerly CIS33)

CIS 240 - Micro Arch & Prog
Presents basic microprocessor concepts including internal architecture, memory, addressing, and control through the use of assembly language. Prerequisite: CIS 217 or CIS 231 Advisory: MATH 124A and ENGR 219. Transfer: CSU; UC. (Formerly CIS40)

CIS 241 - Discrete Structures
Introduction to structures of computer science: numbers, sets, relations, functions and trees; propositional and predicate logic; applications of predicate logic: preconditions, postconditions, invariants, guards; inductive proofs; applications to verification of algorithms; introduction to complexity of algorithms. Prerequisite: MATH 229 and MATH 242 or Math 263 or High School equivalent Transfer: CSU; UC. (Formerly CIS41)[/code]

These are just at the local college. I’m sure a university with a halfway decent computer science department would support more.

All start with C (Minus web/mobile/database classes). 231-233 use Java.

Read full topic

item.title: Html
item.dc:creator: @Pure_Slay Pure Slay
item.description:
@Pure_Slay wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:18, topic:414781”][quote author=Pure Slay link=topic=516742.msg3752532#msg3752532 date=1316140361]

NO! DON’T USE BASIC!

Use Java, C#, or C++ if you’re trying to start with object oriented programming.
If you’ve learned other languages sure, it doesn’t hurt to know another, but starting with basic will set you back a LOT if you try to ever learn other languages

You do realize that all introductory college level classes start with some form of BASIC.
[/quote]Mine doesn’t? And I completely agree with HcoJustin.[/quote]

That’s odd, because almost every program structure classes that I have looked at, and currently enrolled in. Deal with something related to BASIC. I’m not saying it’s a grand language, nor suggesting to fully learn it. Although it helps new programmers with basic concepts that all programming languages structure. I personally know BASIC, Java, and the mark up language HTML. I can honestly say I had no difficulty changing between them, you just need to realize that every programming language has its own rules and ways of programming it. Some represent similar structure, and syntax which people automatically assume makes it ‘easier’. Regardless, in his position where he doesn’t seem to know any programming language. I’d suggest just looking over examples of it, since it is literally baby programming. That way he understands IF whatever, does this. How to store values to variables, and may understand a bit about loops. If he feels prepared enough that he can just jump into a language, go for it. Although like I mentioned before, most programming logical/structure classes do touch on a language similar to, or is BASIC.

Read full topic

item.title: Html
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

[quote=“Pure Slay, post:16, topic:414781”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=516742.msg3752507#msg3752507 date=1316138978]
NO! DON’T USE BASIC!

Use Java, C#, or C++ if you’re trying to start with object oriented programming.
If you’ve learned other languages sure, it doesn’t hurt to know another, but starting with basic will set you back a LOT if you try to ever learn other languages
[/quote]

You do realize that all introductory college level classes start with some form of BASIC.[/quote]

My introductory course started with C. High school courses are that ones that teach BASIC, and it is counterproductive if you want to pursue computer science.

BASIC is, in essence, a entirely different type of programming. If you like the Visual Studio IDE, try C#. It has syntax near identical to Java, and you’ll have a much easier time switching languages.

Read full topic

item.title: Html
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

[quote=“Pure Slay, post:10, topic:414781”][quote author=tyb97 link=topic=516742.msg3752327#msg3752327 date=1316132901]

If you are going to learn any programming language, I’d read up on program structure, conventions, how the computer translates what you write to machine code ect. Also, after reading your massive confusion on how a website markup language would benefit you with java, I’d suggest doing the disgusting BASIC language. It’s designed for students on an introductory level in getting started with programming.

Yeah ive heard that BASIC sucks…
[/quote]

Explain to me why it sucks? Usually someone in the position of critique has experience with a given subject before prejudging it.

My point of ^ is to show that you should at least attempt something before getting general assumptions over it. I know TI BASIC, and BASIC. The code structure is awful, the variable names are gross and ‘if’, ‘else’, ‘then’, ‘goto’ makes me want to cry. Regardless, it’s a good introductory level language in somewhat understanding how a program works.[/quote]
I said that i HEARD it sucks, ive never experienced it my self so I’m just telling you what I HEARD and I have no opinion of the language.

Read full topic

[quote=“tyb97, post:9, topic:414781”][quote author=Pure Slay link=topic=516742.msg3752326#msg3752326 date=1316132785]
If you are going to learn any programming language, I’d read up on program structure, conventions, how the computer translates what you write to machine code ect. Also, after reading your massive confusion on how a website markup language would benefit you with java, I’d suggest doing the disgusting BASIC language. It’s designed for students on an introductory level in getting started with programming.
[/quote]
Yeah ive heard that BASIC sucks…[/quote]

Explain to me why it sucks? Usually someone in the position of critique has experience with a given subject before prejudging it.

My point of ^ is to show that you should at least attempt something before getting general assumptions over it. I know TI BASIC, and BASIC. The code structure is awful, the variable names are gross and ‘if’, ‘else’, ‘then’, ‘goto’ makes me want to cry. Regardless, it’s a good introductory level language in somewhat understanding how a program works.
